transcription.text: Hi guys. So yeah, I'm Felix. I work for Ethereum Foundation. I'm one of the maintainers of
Goethrium and I'm also the maintainer of the DEF PDP specifications. So in this talk, I'm
just going to talk about things that happened around DEF PDP in 2018. So yeah, I get to answer
this question every year. So what's DEF PDP? Well, it's a peer-to-peer networking stack. And it's
a system that Ethereum nodes use to talk to each other over the network. So and it has all the
things that PDP networking stacks usually have. So it has a system for finding nodes on the internet
and it has an encrypted transport protocol that you even heard about a bit earlier. It's not the
best, but it does have one. And this is the protocol that the nodes actually use once they are exchanging
data. And I think the important thing to know about DEF PDP mostly is that it's an integrated
networking stack. So all the components work together in a predefined way. And this is great
because it means that the system has certain properties that we can rely on and it's actually
much easier to evaluate the security this way. Because if you know how exactly this stuff is
going to be used, then it's easy to reason about. So there are around 10 implementations of DEF
PDP right now. So you can see them listed here. Most of these implement, like most of the DEF
PDP implementations are part of some kind of Ethereum blockchain client. But it's not all blockchains.
So there are some implementations that are incomplete or they're just a library that
implement a certain part of it. And DEF PDP isn't just used for the blockchain. It's also used
by other projects like the Swarm distributed file system. Most of the offshoots of the Swarm
file system also use it. And even the status messenger app used it for a long time. But I'm not sure
whether they're still using it or whether they switch to something else by now.
Yeah. So apart from these implementations that are just speaking to protocol, there are a couple
of tools around. Specifically, what we have is a couple of DHT crawlers. Some of them open source,
some of them not. So the most famous one is ethernodes.org, which you can visit and check stats. And
basically, so a DHT crawler explores the node discovery system to see which nodes are around,
and then it lists those on the web page. And then finally, for networking nerds,
this year, consensus has released wire shocker sectors for the protocols. And I'm actually really
happy about that because it means it's much easier now to debug issues with a protocol because I
can just load it up in wire shock and see what is the node doing. And it labels all the packets
that are being sent on the wire by name and things like that. So this is a really helpful thing.
All right.
Let's talk about the live network for a bit. So we're still alive, I guess.
[LAUGHTER]
We have about 12,000 ethernodes just like last year. At least that's what ethernodes says.
And the number of DHT participants is actually quite a bit higher because when you look at ether
nodes, what you see on the front page is ethernodes, which ethernodes has decided that this node
is part of the mainnet. But actually in the discovery, you'll find a bunch more nodes that are doing
all kinds of stuff. Like there are other blockchains which have somehow imported DEF VDP,
there are swarm nodes, there are all kinds of nodes listed there. So you can actually find a
lot more nodes than just those. Oh, right. I forgot something. Yeah. Actually, we haven't,
in 2018, there haven't been any new attacks. So this is, oh, I'm also happy about that.
So in general, we're not seeing a lot of network level attacks. So most of the attacks on Ethereum
have been on the consensus protocol level. But on the network level, we haven't actually seen
any malicious activity as far as we know it least in 2018. So there was not a major
network disruption. But what we did see was that there was a research paper was published in the
beginning of the year by researchers at the University of Boston, where they explored the
possibility of an eclipse attack on the Ethereum discovery network. But fortunately for us, this
this was disclosed responsibly through the bounty program. So they
sent the paper to us a month in advance. And we could actually read it before it was published,
and we could mitigate the issues. And I'll talk a bit about that later.
So yeah, this is now the section where we talk about what happened in terms of development
in 2018. So the first new thing is actually kind of old. So all the specs were rewritten.
And if you read the old spec, it was just one document. Maybe you'll understand why. So it was
really hard to read. It was incomplete at times. You couldn't really figure out
what the semantics of the protocol were. Half of the document was stuff that never got implemented,
which is a big bunch of notes, basically. So yeah, I'm a bit proud to say that the specs are now
much more readable and they're up to date. And yeah, just in general, I've split up the specs
into multiple parts. So I feel like it should all be a lot nicer now. And
we have a test suit now. So this is something that I'm very excited about. Frank
has joined the Goethrium team very recently and he has created a PewDiePie networking test suit
based on the Hive tool. So Hive is a tool that we use for testing the consensus between clients.
And it's also used for testing the RPC interface to the clients. So now we can test the PewDiePie
networking as well. And Goeth, Parity, Aleth, and EthereumJ are hooked up to this test suit and
Trinity is being added. Well, it's been being added since a couple months now. So it's like,
it's going to be done any second. But yeah, it will eventually also be there. And really,
like adding a client to Hive isn't all that hard. So I think this is a huge success.
So in Goeth, what's happened in Goeth? So in the beginning of the year, we were really busy
implementing the mitigation for the Eclipse attack. And basically, the way the attack works is that
a node can be surrounded on the discovery level with attacker nodes. And it won't be able to
find any kind of honest node, because all this will know about is like these
attackers that were spawned specifically to bring this node down. And the way we approached
mitigation was to introduce IP limits on the connectivity. And so basically, you have to have
a nice looking IP address to connect. Yeah, something like that. And we also reworked how
the discovery tables work so that the table can be overrun by attackers so easily. And then later
in the year, we've introduced support for ENR throughout the goal P2P codebase. I'll have
something about ENR later. If that doesn't mean anything to you, it's fine. And we've
modularized the discovery code in general. So we're now ready to actually plug in different
pure discovery mechanisms. And this is massively going to help with adoption of some of the new
changes. But most of the changes to the P2P codebase haven't had any kind of immediate impact on
the connectivity. So, you know, as a user of Gathya, you're not going to like see,
I don't know, any improvements, basically. It's, yeah, it's basically mostly in prep work.
And then as Guillaume mentioned, we've done this experiment to run Deaf P2P applications on
LIP P2P. So since you already talked about it so much, I'm just going to skip it now. So it was,
I think the experiment was successful. And we have a pretty clear roadmap now of how to integrate
LIP P2P into the whole Deaf P2P thing. Okay, so there are some ongoing changes to the low-level
protocols. So independent of any actual implementation. And yeah, so what I've done
this year is to just, I've published three EAP drafts. The first one is EAP778. That's Ethereum
node records. And this is kind of at the heart of it. So Ethereum node records are a new concept. It's
like a small document format with node metadata. It's a bit like business cards for nodes. And in
those business cards, the nodes can declare transport capabilities and application capabilities in
all these kinds of things. And then they can be relayed through some medium. And then up next,
we have this EAP868, which is a tiny specification that integrates node records into the existing
discovery protocol. So this one's really short. And then finally, we have something new, which is
the last item. And that one is an entirely new mechanism for discovering nodes based on DNS.
So it basically allows you to find node records behind a certain DNS name. And it's totally
independent of the of the distributed hash table. So yeah, you know, so what's that about?
So maybe I'll, it's when people look at the EONR specification,
they can sometimes, well, they come back to me and they say, well, what can I use this for? I mean,
this is like, you know, there are almost no details in the EAP about, you know, potential uses.
And it's a document format. I mean, how does that relate to the grand scheme of things?
So the thing about EONR is that it's more like, it's like a medium for negotiating
all kinds of capabilities that nodes have. And it can be about hard to imagine like which
capabilities are actually worth negotiating between nodes. So I'll just have a couple
examples for you guys now. So one of the things that makes me excited about EONR is that it gives
us the option to switch to a zero round trip and encryption scheme. So if two nodes learn about
each other in some discovery system, what the discovery system can do for them is it can relay
key material, which can be used to pre-compute secrets for a connection. And this is actually
really nice because it means that as soon as a connection between those two nodes is created,
the nodes can start sending data that's relevant to the application pretty much within the first byte
because most of the secrets that are needed to encrypt their communication are already pre-computed
before the connection was even created. And yeah, so I feel like this is a pretty useful feature,
but what we need for that obviously is a way to like relay this initial key material. And this is
where EONR can help. The second thing is well, transport options. So this is something that
also makes sense to negotiate upfront because like Guillaume told you, we have this ambitious plan
to use some of the lipidope transport offerings in our Fp2P stack. But in order to make this work,
well, if you have a node that speaks lipidope and you have another that wants to talk to it,
that other node needs to know whether lipidope is supported. And this isn't really something you
can just sort of try. And you can poke the node and then see it was not responding, but that just
takes super long. And the right solution here is to just know that this node is capable of
speaking lipidope. And so for these kinds of things, it's obviously very useful if the node can
declare upfront in some kind of system that it's compatible with whatever transport you want to speak.
And then finally, there's another thing which is negotiating prices. So what kind of prices?
Well, so in systems like the Ethereum like client or swarm, you have something called an incentive
system. So in an incentive system on the network level, there are clients and there are servers
and the clients pay the servers for whatever bandwidth they're using. And while that bandwidth
comes at a certain price. And if you have an incentive system set up, then there's a market
for servers, obviously, because some servers are going to have one price and other servers
going to offer another price. And as a client, you want to connect to servers that are sort of
like in your price range, right? I mean, you don't have an infinite budget. You need a server
that gives you the most, how do you say bang for the buck, I guess? And so to make this work,
if you can already know upfront that a certain server for say swarm can offer you data at a
certain price that can influence your connectivity decision as a client. So you're obviously going
to prefer the servers that are, you know, match your price expectations, right?
And let's just go and look a bit at how the DNS discovery works, because this is like the new thing.
So the DNS discovery is a bit different from the others because it doesn't talk about improving
any existing protocol. It's a totally new protocol. And we've come up with this scheme
because we want a replacement for bootstrap node lists. So in most clients, what you'll find is
there's a hard-coded list of bootstrap nodes, usually it's not that long, and these nodes are
the initial entry point into the network. So when you want to talk to Ethereum blockchain,
you've got to start somewhere. So you've got to find someone who's on that blockchain more or less,
talk to them first and then find all the others who are also, you know, into this thing. And
maintaining these lists is, you know, annoying because if we want to add a node to it, then we
can just put in a source code. People can download some release, a new release of the client,
and then they'll have it. But we'd rather much rather have a list that's dynamic that can be
updated on the fly and the list is like very, very long, right? So we, you know, for initial entry
points, you better give people some options. So what we envision for DNS discovery is a system
that can dynamically, with the help of the distributed hash table, create a massive list of nodes that
have a certain uptime and that have certain capabilities, like, let's say, like a big list of main of
mainnet nodes. Well, then we compile them into a certain format and publish that at some DNS
provider. And, well, and then clients would be able to find them there. And, well, that's DNS
discovery for you. All right. And there is one more feature. So the thing is the system also
includes a certain, it's a bit like a web of trust. So one node list can actually refer to another
node list using the DNS name of the list and the public key. And this means that, well, certainly
the list can sort of authorize each other and we can, we can group them into meta lists and things
like that. Right. So, yeah, the EPS. So Ethereum node records is implemented in Go Python and
JavaScript so far. The extension is implemented in Go but isn't, isn't merged in the master branch
and no discovery via DNS is implemented in Go and Python. But the deployer tool that, that
moves it to, moves it to a DNS provider isn't really done yet. Right. And now I had just have
two more minutes, I guess, more or less. It says two there. So I'm just, I look at this clock.
And so I'll just talk about a bit about what's next. So we have an ongoing discussion with the
sharding team. The theorem research team about how we can, how we can join the efforts because
the Ethereum sharding right now, the networking is based on lippy to pee. So I feel this is a
good decision with lippy to pee because it gives them a lot of options to try out. But obviously,
like I myself want to like feed my improvements that I'm working on, you know, on the fund,
Ethereum foundation payroll, I want to, you know, feed those improvements into the sharding. So
I feel like the things that that we're doing here to, to improve the PDP, these things can
actually benefit sharding in the long run. But right now there isn't much overlap. But like I
said, we have an ongoing discussion. And then the biggest challenge that sharding faces is just
that they need a system where peers can, can be switched really quickly and we're trying to make
that work. Right, I'm going to skip this part. And I'm going to just quickly say before I have to go
that there's a big plan for 2019 to offer a deaf PDP as a WebAssembly module. So that you guys,
if you ever want to use deaf PDP, you don't have to use Go or like another good implementation, but
probably that's going to be Go because it's the best. Yeah. But yeah. So this is a plan that we have
and thanks.
[Applause]
